This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: MOTORING IN THE SUDAN
div.p: PRACTICABILITY OF ROADS.

The following intereating report on a motor trip from Khartonm North to Jebel Geili and baok (180 miles), ia by Bimbashi Potter, Assistant Direotor of Worka :— The original intention waa to make a trip along the Kharonm-Kaasala road as far aa Atbara (223 miles). Aa the atart had to be poatponed, however, and a breakdown might hâve canaed me to miss the Bahr-el-Ghazal boat, I deoided to try aa far aa Geili (90 miles) only, as thia wonld give a good idea of how the oar wonld ron on the cotton soit which extendsfrom Geseima to the Atbsra. A atart was made from the Works Dept. enoloanre, Khartonm North, at 7.16 a.m. on 22nd November and Wad Sereira waa reaohed at 5.30 p.m. Dedooting the time taken in inspeoting the wella the oar had taken 8 honra 20 minutes to oover tbi*. distance of 56 miles. Thia slow rate of progreaa waa due mainly to bad petrol which waa pioked up at one of the wella. This petrol had been allowed to stand in the son for a fortnight contrary to ordera and had in addition beoome mixed with water in aome way. The resnlt of thia waa that the aparking pings beoame ohoked with soot and it waa neoessary for a part of the rime to olean theae every 200 yards or ao, eacb stop taking 15 minâtes, ail of which time ia inolnded in the 8 honra 20 minâtes. A atart waa made the following morning at 6.30 a.m. and Geili (34 mileB) waa reaohed at 9.45 a.m., a atay of 30 minâtes being made to inapeot the new well at Wad De> g*lia. The retnrn jonrney from Geili waa commenced at 11 30 a.m. and ail went well nntil a point near Wadi Soba abont 10 miles from Khartonm waa reaohed when the petrol feed pipe broke. Tbia haviDg been mended it now being dark and 114 miles having been ron in a little over 8 honra it waa deoided to oamp for the night The following morning a run of a little nnder an hoor brought tbe oar into the inoloanre at Khartonm North. The total tnnning time taken to oover 180 miles waa 17 honra 20 mi nntes, which inolnded ail atopa due to heavy sand and neoessary oleaning or cooling of ma ohinery, etc. The road was fennd to be aomewhat aandy in places, bat thia willghortly beremedied by a party at présent at work on it In low-lying plaoea where water had atood in the raina and animais bad passed over it, the gronnd waa rongh and fnll of holea. The long gra8B hid the latter and made carefnl driving neoessary. Where a good deal ot traffic had been over the soft ootton aoil the oar ran well, leaving hardly any impression, bat the natives nnfortnnately oonfine themselvea to a single very narrow track aa far aa possible, bat the nnmber ot theae ia inoreasiug and with eacb one the work of the motor will be deoreased. A word of praiae ia due to Mr. Waters for the way in which the oar ran and the way in which he-atnok to his work aa the atrain of driving throngh Band and on a rongh road covered with graaa ia only realized by thoae who hâve attempted it. div.head: THE BARRAGE.
div.p: A PLEASANT DAY'S OUTING.

There ia no more pleasant spot near Cair for a day's onting tban the Barrage, where the time may be passed away either in the beanti fol gardons alongside of it or in prospeoting that marvellons monument to engineering skil'. Time and weather allowing, the trip down the rivar has, of ooorse, its attraotions ; bn! when time ia limited and weather none too certain it \a far more convenient and less fatigning to nndertake the short jonrney by tram and epend ail the hoors available on the apot. Trains to the Barrage rnn from the Caire central station at varions timea throoghont the day, at 8.40 and 10.20 in the morning, and at 1.15, 3.40, and 5.40 in the afternoon, the return joarneys being at 9.35 and 12.5 a.m., and at 2.50, 4.40, 6.20, and 9.30 p.m. The jonrney only takes aome tfcirty minutes either way ; and it ia qaite possible to aee ail one wants in either the forenoon or afternoon and still get baok to Cairo in exoellent time for either lnnch or dinner. Thia branch of the Egyptian State Railway rnns tbrongh coltivat-ed oonntry ail the way, paasing Sbonbra and Calionb en ronte, and the carnages are most oomfortabie and of easy action. The Barrage a ation ia at the eaat end of the hoge stinotore whiob Bpreads its lengtb aoroaa the head of tbe twin rivera aud the isthmna which dividea tbem ; and ontaide the station gates ia foond the tiny trock line along wbich pasaengera are puabed on small trolley oara from end to end of the atopendom wair. There is a frivoloos Earl'a Conrt Exhibition Havoor abont thia latter joorney with its little trolliea and bare-foot pantÎDg attendants, and its ops and downa over the look gates, efo., and qoite an amonnt of amusement and exoitement can be derived from it, as the aame road is nsed by both wayfarer8 and beaata of borden, and the latter are never qnite so happy as when obstrooting the track. The guide-booka give ns ail the details of the Barrage, the nnmbar and action of the alnicea and wafer gates, the dates of its inception and completion, and the historiés of its predeoe6aors. Tho ordinary sight-aeer ia not eüormonaly in-tereated in theae detailp, thongh he cannot fail to be impreased ly the magnitude of its oonccptioD. Neitber can he aee mnoh of its working from the roadway on the anpe'-atrnotnre with its curions Norman oaatellated gates, beyond the myaterions apparatna wbich ia oonnected with the opening of the slnices. Bat if further information in tho matter of weira and dama ia required, there i9 an ex oallent muséum within the gardons wbich oontaiua many intereating modela of the artificiel wateiway, dams, and réservoirs in varions parts of Egypt where the visitor oan at leianre digeat tbeir workinga and form an opinion of tbeir nae. Thia mnaeum ia quite de'erving a viait, the modela are most elaborate, and thoae which show the oon-atraotion of the cernent oores and wall fonnda tiona of thia great Nile Barrage are moat entertaining and instructive. Outaida the attraotion of the Barrage itself, and yet indiaaolnbly oonnected with it, are the marvellonaly laid ont gardons, which are well worth the viait in themaelvea. Here are broad atretohe8 of emerald turf, magnificeut olumps of ahady treeB, woeping willows, feathery bam-booa, hage acacias, and enoalyptns mingled with palms and aloes and many floweriDg shrnbs and plants. Rnstio Beats are placed in ooay corners, and shady walks anfold themsel ves leading from vista to vista of still more perfeot lovelinesa. The.Menoufieh Canal dividea theae gardena, which cover the isthmns, and on the further Bide ia the wide terraoe wrih its flighta of atepa where the lannohea and pa88enger boata are moored. The roadway-whioh rnna throogh the gardons and conneots the two brancher of the Barrage is bordered by a handsom9 avenne of aoacia treea from whenoe gates lead to the gardena lying on either aide. If only the anthoritiea wonld permit of a good rest and tea-houae in the vioinity ofthe gardena and poBt office, one can aee tbese gardena becoming one of the most popnh. r resorta ronnd Cairo, or if only the far famed Wagons-Lit CompaDy oould see their w*y to opening up a small bot well kept restaurant in the station, many thîrsty visitora wonld be their debtors. At the présent moment there ia no accommodation worthy ot the name to be reoommeuded to the European visitor. Should time and energy allow, a visit ahonld be made to the little native village which stretches from the station alongside the river. Here on market days an amostng hoor may be spent wandering past the booths and staHs which line the way with their maltitndinous wareu : piles of vegetables, fruits, and oarious edibles in close cor jonction with stacka of pottery and métal otensds, wbile garments of the latest Mousky pattern with cheap warea from tha German markets joatle alongside of plaintive live stook and native groceries.

div.head: IS GREAT BRITAIN DISLOYAL?
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GaZETTE."

Dear Sir, — The leading article in the "Egyptian Gazette" of Deoember 8, "Is Great Britain Disloyal ?" appears ao nojaat to wbat ia termed the "Mofcber Coantty" that I orave permission for the following remarks.

The firat qootation, aa to Britain's "Fiscal Folly" and her diffionlty of snstainiDg her position among the nations, is qnite nncalled-for, from an Anstralianr beoanse hia oolony haa placed dntiea npon the home-.laod'a manufactures about doable those of German y, and three timea more than those of Beveral other nations who are nnder no obligation to a b, as ia Anstralia.

Great Britain's fisoai polioy ia not folly, bot trne atatesnumahip, when one oonsidera she had by meana of free iood importa to anatain her oongeated population, and to accept in snob, and in a few oaaes in raw mateiial and manufaotnrea, paymeat for the prodaotion of her teeming artizina and intereat on loans whioh foreigp nations not having, like the British Empira possession of gold mines oonld not pay in gold.

If an example of fiscal folly were needed, a glauce at the resalt of the prohibitive daties Anstralia levied npon produots of the New Hebrid8a, thna throwing the plantera there of onr own raoe into the arma of Franoe who in New Galedonia and elsewhere permitted the produoe of the islands praotioally tree entry, ia an admirable epeoimen. When having thna rnined the prospecta of British aettlera dealing in British colonial neighbonring marketa the Motherland waa aaked to daim from Franoe to retnrn what by her wisdom and liberaUty she had gained. If we sncoeeded and handed over to Anstralia the ialands in question we shoold then hâve the monstrona Australien tari fi againat db eatablished to onrinjury therein.

Yon tell na Mr, Herbert Strong s ya there ia not any sentimental love for Anstralia in Britain. It is not correct, bat if it were ia it not excusable when we fiud that oolony's doty i againat ua ia the higheit in the world,and if oot working man go tbare aeeking promiaad employ j ment tbey are refused permission to land. Our fellow anbjeots in India, who in oase of war ' wonld shed their blood to defend Anstralia if oalled npon, are prohibited from Australien soit and even from obkaining a livelih >od in British ships trading from India to Anstralia.

Britain is taanted with embrsoing the Frenoh, cringing to Amerioa, by which I sap- ! pose is meant the United States, ahaking 1 hands with Rassia, and pLoating Garmany. Thia ia tbe description given of the sqo-oesafal diplomacy of King Edward VIL, which every chv cellery inmf arope views witb admiration. We hâve, thanks to him, become more friendly with France, and why not ? Her proteotive dutiea agiinat as are not ao onerous m Anstralia's, and yet we do not at oir expeuse provide her with an army and navy and diplomatie aervioe ail the wjrld over.

To anyone whô knowa the inner aide of ( recent diplomaoy, the idea that we bave plaoated Germany aince she placed an on- ( fair interprétation npon onr treaty with her regarding China, is absnrd. A shake-hand with Rusais, now tuât Ly onr alliance with [ Japan we indiieotly oaused her misfortunea, ia aurely a diplomatie achievement. Mach as we admire the Japaoese, it muât be re-membered her triumph waa that of a non-Christian nation, and wby ahonld we décliné to be friendly to Russia in the time of her weakDeaa ? To pleaae a jonrualiat at Adelaidt who risk-i for ua tha valaab'e Japaneae agroe-ment by refnaing to permit the ohildren of our ally to live on hia preoiona ahorea ? Théo we bave "oringed to the United , Btatea." When ? Becanae when we fonnd that the Alaska Treaty, wbich might hâve been ignored had Canada 25 yeare ago oooopied the diapated point», was dtaftod for the express pnrpose of preventing collisions be-tween Rusaian aailora and Canadian trappers, and ao therefore worded aa to prevent the latter aooeaa to the sea, rendered the Cina-dian oontentiona oontrary to its iuteution, wa gave up two barren ialands at Port Bimpson to effeot a settlement.

In regard to the présent diapnte aa to Newfonndland'a fiiheriea, it ia to be regrettrd that the latter, not being a member of the Dominion of Canada, ia in saoh an nneq 'al position with regard to the States, bat it mnat be remembered that large nnmbera of the Newfoondlandera who the British Admiralîy at great expense trained as naval seamen hâve beoome q a ar ter mas tara and non-oommia sioned offioera in the United States Navy.

We are told of onr "fiscal folly," bat it ahonld be knowa that by colonial action our polioy il not all in onr own banda. It ia now only by oonrteiy that Germany aad aome other oountriea permit m to trade nn'V the favoared nation olanaea, f ir legally oolo-nial high daties on tbe:r go ids put us out of the oatego y. As they are part if the Empire ail our home exporta to tbese foreigo ooantriea oould jostly be put on the piohi bitive, or bighest, soales.

That this was not the requit when firat suoh colonial importa wero oommenoed was due to British dip'omaoy and the générons ao-CYptanoe by the aggrievod Power#, that we oonld not oompel self governing oolouiea to rednoe thrir tarifff, and ao for fiscal purpoaea we were not a single unit.

Thia exoaae of course failed when Canada, beoanae of onr nnity of Empire, gave a prefer-enoe to British gooda, alleging Germany had do right to oomplain beos^e England and her ooloniee formed one single nation, Germany retaliated upon Canada alone but did not place all the Fritish Empire ont of the favoared nation danse. As to lack of ayopathy with Canada, aak the atrnggling: traders and meohanios of EnglAftd and Sootlacd who are taxed to-nain-tain a Navy and Aimy to defend Canada if need be,or the hankari and inveatora ofLondon and GlMgow who hâve ponred their millions into the laps of Cànada to exploit her reapnroea.

No, Sir, Great Britain ia not dialoyal ; the «entries standing at their posta ail the world. over to keep open the oolonial trade ronte?, and the navy which for the same objeot gnards the eeas, prove it If there ia any dis oyalty seek it where Great Britain's ohildren are not ajlowed a haven on the sborea her people ahield from. ooDqueat, or her worker'a prodnoti are taxed 50 per œnt, to keep them away, where their fellow-oitizena if only ot different akin tint may not land and where their ally'a oit'zena are wnrned away —Yonra obediently,
Britannicds
London, Deoember 20.

div.head: COMMISSION MUNCIPALE
div.p: ( Communication Officielle )

La Commission Municipals s'est réunie le 2 janvier 1907 à4 1/2p.m. sons la présideooe de S.B. le Dr. SohiesB Pacha. Ko ouvrant la uéanoe, S E. le Président adresse la bienvenue à M. King Lewis, non-veQ directeur générai des Douanes, et eBt persuadé que la môme bienveillance qui a g?idé les rapporta de son prédéoeasenr avec la Municipalité, l'inspirera également pour le plus grand bien de oette oité. La Commission s'associe- entièrement aux sentiments exprimés par le Président M. King Lewié remercie. Communication est donnée d'une lettre de S E. le Ministre de l'Intérieur du 30 décembre 1906 approuvant la déoirion prise par la Commission tendant à rattr1^n ao Consulat de Franoe à Alexandrin 'CÀ*e somme de L.E. 11,000 destinée* fr porter tr Iï.B. 25,000 la dépense de construction* du* nouvel hôtel consulaire but les qnaie, M. Kamel Bey Teymoar interpelle l'Administration au srjet de la question de la confection de la oorniche. Quatre mois hb sont écoulés depuis que la Commission a pris nue décision définitive au sujet de cette route dont l'exécution est attendre aveo impatience et cependant rien n'a été fait ; il demande que par une confirmation do ses premières décisions, la Commission exprime encore une fois, ' en'y* insistant, son désir formel de voir réaliser J oe projet aoqnol do reste des ionds spéciaux ont été déjk affeotés. | L'Admioistrateur répond que l'absence en congé de 1'Ingéuieor eu chef, suivie do 1a période de transition oréée par le changement de direction du servioe technique ont été cause? que l'exécution do projet, qui nécessite du reste des études de détail, a été retardée Maintenant que le nouvel ingénieur en chef, arrivé aujourd'hui même, va prendre possession de ses fonctions, l'administration donnera tous ses soins à la réalisation do projet de la oor* niche. Après un éohauge de vue0, la Commission demaudrqu'en attendant l'aplanissement des difficultés provenant*' do l'incorporation » à la corniche de oertaioea parties de propriétés j privées, l'administration commence l'exécution du tronçon en continuation des quais sur les terrains appartenant à la Municipalité. I M, Salvago développe son interpellation relative k l'état des routes de la ville. Il dit que ' l'entretien laisse souvent à désirer et qu'on ne songe à porter remède aux détériorations que Tusure des ohaoaséea entraîne que lorsqu'elles J s'aggravent au point dî constituer une séri ease incommodité au lieu de les maintenir en bon état d'entretien au moyeu d'une surveillance oonçtante1 et méthodique. Il signale, aussi, leÇéUbremont tie certaines enceintes de propriéfefiprivéôs, qui par leur état de ruine, ODnetitu^t pour loi passants un véritable danger. Mais l'abus le pluB manifeste est celui commis par les occupants de la voie publique. SanB être partisan des mesures radicales de suppression, il trouve que la Municipalité devrait pteudre les mesures les plus restrictives pour empêcher que certaines mes déjà étroites ou sillonnées par les lignes des tramways, soient employées par las riveraine pour l'exercice d'industries variées au grand détriment de la circulation publique. », Les mesures à prendre devraient s'inspirer de certaines règles qui détermineraient quels sont les personnes qui peuvent oooapèr la voie pu blique dedans qu0U0 oeaare celle ci peut être ocoupéeî jpl y a, en effet, à envisager des situa-tjoni spaualerqae recommanda un intérêt en i qaelqnôjaorte'pûblio, tel que, par exemple, lea occupations à consentir aux cafetiers. \ M. Salvago termine on disant qu'une réorganisation du service de la voie publique s'impose et qae pour établir une surveillance plus efficace et déterminer lea responsabilités, il serait utile de désigner des inspecteurs divisionnaires» qui devraient ohaoun rendre compte do quartier qui serait confié à leur vigilance. Divers membres prennent la parole sur cette question. Tout en partageant les appréciations de M. Salvago ai sujet de? routas, plusieurs membres considèrent que l'insuffisance des moyens financiers de la Municipalité est poor beaucoup dans l'état de choses dont on ce plaiht, l'extension de la ville et des nonvaux travaax entrepris ayant rendu le badget d'entretien peu eu rapport avec le? besoins qui augmentent de joar en jour. En ce qui concerne 1'oooupation de la voie publique, les observations de M. 8âfvago sont unanimement approuvées, mais il a été romarqaé que les mesures à prendre devraient se concilier aveo les nécessités inhérentes tant aa climat qa'à la configuration même des rontéB. Un remède tout indiqué serait l'oaverture de larges voies et l'élargissement de ce'ies qai existent per mettant; ainsi de donner pins d'espace et d'aération. L'Administrateur dit qi'ün 00 qni oonoen e les enceintes délabrée*, le Conseil da Tantim ne marque pa?, toutes lesfois, que leur état de ruine constitue un danger, de prescrire la dé molition, mais il outre passerait ses droits et risquerait de ne pas être snivi par l'aatorité jadioiaire si paretiler mesure était prescrite sans quelle sOitjastifiée par un danger réel. Pour les rootes, l'Administrateur dit q i' 1 y a certainement beaucoup à Tain», mais que tes améliorations sont surtout subordonnées à la création de ressources nouvelles pouvant donner an budget ordinai 0 une élasticité qui lui manque. Il espère cependant que par la ng^jse eu prat;qui du projet de réorganisation qajl a^teimis et qui concorde aveo les vue? de ,décentralisation exposées par M. Salvage lad \ministration, malgré les ressources limitées (îônt elle dispose, arrivera à donuer satisfaction eu désir si légitime de la Commission. PafcàtftH fc^qnottlo^ d^Tdbeuftfoa tiw' !ft* voie publique, M. Chataway dit quo beaucoup de progrès-ont été réalisés jnaqmici, màiB que la principale préoccupation de l'administration était de reoberoher lea moyens pouvant mieux assurer la Municipalité oontre lea personnes ocouptnt abodî'venâënt la voie publique. A la suite de démaVbbeepressantes auprès du Ministère, des instructions viennent enfin d'être données à la police en vue d'agir sur la requisition de la Municipalité contre tout contrevenant. Par ltf collai o-àtion des deax admîbîs* trations, il est à espérer que des améliorations très sensibles seront obtenues. Le sèrviœ de l'occupation recevra da reste- une nouvelle organisation dont le principal objet sera l'axer-oice d'une surveillance des pins rigoureuses. Après un échange d'idées, k? Commission décide d'inviter l'Administration à présenter dans les dear mois, après avùiT demandé l'avis des chef? do servioe compétents, nn rapport but les mesures à prendre pour améliorer l'ensemble des service* de là voirie et de l'oooupation do la voie publique. 8ur avis favorable de la Délégation et vu les justifications présentées, la Commission décide d'exonérer un fournisseur de l'amende encourue poar lotard dans les livraisons de pierres. Uu avis da Comité dn Contentieax de l'Etat snr une question relative aux notifications à faire aux consulats en cas de Baisie administrative, est renvoyé an Comité du Contentieux Municipal. Examinant les demandes présentées pour la location de divers terrains sur les quais, la Commission, après un échange de vues, décide, Bor la proposition de M. Eicoffier, de porter à l'ordre du joar de la prochaine réunion de la Commission la question de la location des terrains en vue de trancher définitivement le point de savoir ai la Municipalité consentira ou non à adopter le système des locations. Une proposition du même Conseiller tendant à accorder une remise de l'impôt foncier pendant cinq ans anx personnes qui construiront sur les quais dans les trois ans qui suivront fabdication, sera également scumise à l'assemblée. En attendant, les demandes présentées pour location ne doivent pas taire .obstacle aux ventes. . Les propositions relatives à l'exonération do la taxe sur voitures et bestiaux pour motifs de aerrioe public ou antres, sont renvoyées pour examen aux Comités des Finances et do Contention!. M. 8alvago développe ea proposition tendant à l'admission de la presse aux séances de la Commission. Après on échange d'idées, la Commission, moins trois voix, est en principe favorable à ta proposition de M. Salvago et renvoie la question au Comité du Contentieax pouf être étudiée aa point de vne légal. La séauce est levée k 7h. \ p.m. Alexandrîa ftairkét1 Cortipariÿ, ÉtÜ.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
World-wide reputation.
